oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bunker or guard station on Vung Chua Mountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One of the many concrete bunkers on Vung Chua Mountain that defended the signal station. The photograph was likely taken at night and is illuminated by the base lights.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mountains; Military facilities; Bunkers; Forts & fortifications
Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ammons stated the bunkers usually were manned by two men and typically contained an M-60 machine gun and an M79 grenade launcher. Bunker duty was one of the most common assignments on Vung Chua. Ammons worked in the radio room and frequently called the bunkers late at night to make certain that the occupants were awake and alert.
